POEME.AUTRE: Yet there are souls, proud Bard, who feel thee not, Bounded and blind with but a single thought; Who'd tear the laurels from thine honoured brow, And force us grovelling to their gods to bow; Proudly thou answer'st in yet nobler strain And shak'st the vermin from thy regal mane. Thy fame hath been the theme of loftiest lyres, In their rich sweil my feeble song expires, Yet spurn not, laurelled head, the wreath I twine Though all unworthy this poor lay of mine! More than the rich man's gifts the orphan's mite Found larger favour in the Man-God's sight. I yet am young, and years may give me strength To reach the grandeur of my aim at length; Then will I tell thee all l've felt and feel And all my bosom's gratitude reveal.
